title: Smart Buffalo Farm Management System Design and Scientific Data Analysis Application: Experimental-Measurement-Variable-Based Approach

context.prior_knowledge: Basic agricultural management knowledge, fundamental smartphone app usage skills, foundational understanding of scientific experimental data interpretation (measurement, recording, inference), and awareness of variable control and evidence-based conclusion methodologies
context.additional_context: Learners aim for advanced expertise in managing small-scale buffalo farms, focusing on developing field problem-solving skills using smart technologies. Conduct practice-centered projects in a BYOD environment, learning to analyze environmental data (temperature, humidity, pH) and buffalo biometric data collected via IoT sensors through scientific methods (observation/measurement/experimentation). Emphasizes data interpretation skills for evidence-based decision-making.

learning_goals: Applying the ADDIE model, learners will execute the agricultural management app design process step-by-step and establish a data collection system based on scientific inquiry principles (hypothesis formulation-experimentation-analysis-conclusion).

Design digital system functionalities for record-keeping, health monitoring (biometric measurements and symptom analysis), and breeding management (genetic variable analysis and experimental design) in buffalo farms.

Applying user-centered design principles (accessibility, intuitiveness, efficiency), learners will create an app interface prototype in Figma or Adobe XD that incorporates at least three farmer requirements and integrates real-time chart visualization of experimental data (e.g., crop growth patterns, soil analysis results).

Over a 4-week intermediate course, learners will develop a farm management app prototype using agricultural IoT sensor data and implement at least three scientifically analyzable functions (data measurement/recording, pattern analysis/inference, result prediction/verification) applicable to real farm scenarios (e.g., irrigation system control, buffalo health monitoring). They will achieve scores of 80% or higher in at least two of three rubric categories (Functionality, Usability, Practical Applicability).
difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
